etymologies: Old English thawian (verb), of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch dooien. The noun (first recorded in Middle English) developed its figurative use in the mid 19th century

definitions: (of ice, snow, or another frozen substance, such as food) become liquid or soft as a result of warming

examples.text: the river thawed and barges of food began to reach the capital

shortDefinitions: become liquid or soft as result of warming up

definitions: the weather becomes warmer and melts snow and ice.
shortDefinitions: weather becomes warmer and causes snow and ice

definitions: make (something) warm enough to become liquid or soft

examples.text: European exporters simply thawed their beef before unloading

shortDefinitions: make something warm enough to become liquid or soft

definitions: (of a part of the body) become warm enough to stop feeling numb

examples.text: Ryan began to feel his ears and toes thaw out

shortDefinitions: become warm enough to stop feeling numb

definitions: make or become friendlier or more cordial

examples.text: she thawed out sufficiently to allow a smile to appear

shortDefinitions: make or become friendlier or more cordial

definitions: a period of warmer weather that thaws ice and snow
shortDefinitions: period of warmer weather that thaws ice and snow

definitions: an increase in friendliness or cordiality

examples.text: a thaw in relations between the two countries
